title: Global Bauer execs in town to work out PacMags deal
text:
Last week, Seven confirmed to the ASX it was in discussions regarding its magazine assets, after The Australian Financial Review revealed it was poised to net $40 million from a potential sale to Bauer.

A combined business would see titles such as Marie Claire, Who, New Idea, Better Homes and Gardens and Girlfriend join The Australian Women's Weekly, Woman's Day, Gourmet Traveller and Elle in the Bauer stable.

According to Enhanced Media Metrics Australia and Nielsen data, Bauer and PacMags in July 2019 had a combined print and digital audience of 7.9 million people aged 14 and over.

On Friday, Seven locked in two deals, including a merger with regional affiliate Prime Media and the sale of its Western Australia radio business Redwave to Southern Cross Austereo for $28 million.

The sale of Redwave and PacMags, as well as $11 million in cost synergies, up to an extra $25 million in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, and potential revenue opportunities from the Prime deal should it be completed, will help Seven's balance sheet which has been weighed down by debt.

Under the deal, Prime shareholders will receive 0.4582 Seven shares for each share they own in the regional network, valuing the company at about $64 million. Seven shareholders will own 90 per cent of the proposed combined group, with Prime shareholders owning the final 10 per cent. The offer was a 3 per cent discount on Thursday's close share price before the deal was announced on Friday.

Former Domain chief executive-turned-regional publisher Antony Catalano continues to hang around Seven's move on Prime. Sources indicated he was trying to contact major Prime shareholders, including Bruce Gordon, who owns rival regional broadcaster WIN and has so far not publicly expressed a view on the transaction.

Mr Gordon holds 11.6 per cent of Prime shares. He also has another 8.1 per cent cash-settled share swap in his rival broadcaster, taking his total economic interest to 19.7 per cent. Mr Gordon is the largest shareholder in Nine, publisher of the Financial Review.

Spheria portfolio manager Matt Booker, whose fund owns 14.4 per cent of Prime, expressed support for the deal on Friday.

It remains unclear what Mr Catalano is planning to do. Seven holds a change of control provision over Prime so would need to approve any alternate deal. Seven and Prime sources remained confident shareholders will support the transaction. Representatives for Mr Gordon did not return calls on Sunday.

In June, Mr Catalano finalised the $125 million acquisition of Australian Community Media (ACM) from Nine.

Mr Catalano is known to be keen to build a larger cross-platform regional media business and it's believed he has been interested in Prime. There has been speculation Mr Catalano and ACM were the party that scooped up around 3 per cent of Prime when Mr Gordon was forced by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to sell down his total exposure to the stock to under 20 per cent last month.

The ACM executive chairman remained quiet over the weekend about whether he intended to take any further action. There has been speculation Mr Catalano has increased his holding in Prime, which he would be required to disclose within three days if he had passed the 5 per cent substantial shareholder threshold.
description: Sources say executives from Bauer Media have flown into Australia to hash out the potential acquisition of Pacific Magazines.
